summary.topic: my name is myen and i create videos about lessons from my 20s.
summary.summary: videos about lessons in my 20s. they're cinematic reels capturing things i've learned over the years. today, i want to do something different and share lessons specifically from my

summary.topic: today, i want to share lessons from my journey as a content creator over the past year.
summary.summary: my content journey over the past year has been eye-opening. it began right here in this room at bel space with zero subscribers and no youtube channel. my perspectives have evolved significantly since then.

summary.topic: a year ago, i started with zero subscribers and had barely picked up a camera.
summary.summary: channel back then but didn't have Instagram yet, barely knew how to use a camera. now i'm here again, with more eyes on my content.

summary.topic: numbers don't matter as much as my evolving relationship with creating content.
summary.summary: at the end of the day, the numbers don't really matter. what matters is how my relationship with creating content has changed over the past year. that's what i'll focus on in this talk.

summary.topic: it's hard to zoom out and see the full picture while creating.
summary.summary: after almost a year of creating content, it's interesting to analyze how my perspective has changed. zooming out, i can see the full picture and my relationship with creating, which would look like this if depicted on a graph.

summary.topic: my relationship with creating content has been non-linear.
summary.summary: going to dig into different segments of time and what I learned during those phases. starting with when I first began in build space sf1 and started creating YouTube content exclusively.

summary.topic: i started making YouTube videos exclusively and was posting one video per week.
summary.summary: focusing on instagram and posting one youtube video per week with a goal of hitting 5,000 subscribers, but this goal was

summary.topic: my goal of hitting 5,000 subscribers was actually hurting me.
summary.summary: creating during build space took a toll on me; my metrics stayed flat even though i posted videos every week. i kept showing up, but views didn't reach my expectations, and growth didn't happen as i had hoped.

summary.topic: each week that i didn't blow up, i felt lower and lower.
summary.summary: i felt increasingly low, which made me create less content. even when i'd have small wins, the low feeling would return, questioning why things hadn't blown up. this taught me to focus more on...

summary.topic: the first lesson: focus more on inputs rather than outputs.
summary.summary: you can't control who follows you or how many view your content, but you can control how often you show up. focus on the inputs rather than the outputs. consistency is key.

summary.topic: you can't control who follows you but can control how often you show up.
summary.summary: a question i often hear is how often should i show up. personally, i don't like daily posting. i think that's overkill.

summary.topic: i don't like daily posting as it doesn't leave enough time to actually live life.
summary.summary: feeling like i don't have enough time to actually live life because i'm spending too much time editing and making videos. my advice is to find a balance and make sure you're living and feeling inspired, not just creating content.

summary.topic: advise: pick a recurring schedule that still lets you live and feel inspired.
summary.summary: pick a posting cadence that pushes you without compromising your inspiration and life experiences. balance between quantity and quality as you share.

summary.topic: second lesson: when you know you'll keep showing up, you can prioritize quality over quantity.
summary.summary: april lynn, rock's girlfriend and a fellow sf1 member, shared some key advice on content creation. she emphasized that when you're certain you'll consistently show up, especially on tough days, you can prioritize quality over frequent posting. this advice resonated with many in the sf1 cohort who often struggled with balancing video production time and regular content updates.

summary.topic: if unsure of your goals, prioritize consistency.
summary.summary: spending extra time can make you second-guess your goals and lose momentum, especially if a video takes weeks to finish. it's crucial to choose consistency when you're unsure if you'll keep showing up. after finishing sf1, i felt jaded with metrics and decided to move forward without focusing on them.

summary.topic: i tossed metrics out and focused on what brought me joy in creating.
summary.summary: the window, so i started focusing less on the number of subscribers and views. instead, i began prioritizing what brings me joy in creating content. at this point, i let go of the metrics and concentrated on what truly matters to me.

summary.topic: i started letting go of metrics and experimented with longer projects.
summary.summary: spending more time on videos and making things i actually enjoy, i created a unique project unlike my usual content. it involved more people, took longer to release, but reignited my joy in creating. it also pushed me to experiment with short form content.

summary.topic: i opened up to short-form content, realizing it allowed faster experimentation.
summary.summary: initially, i was against short form content because i thought it restricted my creativity. however, i realized it actually let me experiment with ideas more quickly and frequently. in the beginning, i posted randomly and without much effort just to understand the platform.

summary.topic: third lesson: learning to have fun again was pivotal.
summary.summary: you'll often hear me say this: learning how to have fun again has been a pivotal shift for me. it's transformed my content creation, taking ideas from mere thoughts to impactful projects.

summary.topic: fun helps take an idea from a thought to a finished video.
summary.summary: keeping things fun is the key to sticking with your projects and seeing your hard work pay off. people often quit before they see results because they don't enjoy the process. instead of overthinking what others want, focus on what you enjoy creating to avoid the cycle of frustration.

summary.topic: creating purely for fun can help regain momentum.
summary.summary: at this point in my instagram journey, i was creating content that was fun for me but didn't provide much value. while in japan, i made cinematic reels of beautiful sights which got few views initially. eventually, as i created more for fun, i started to gain momentum.

summary.topic: after gaining momentum, look at the intersection of fun and impact.
summary.summary: start with what interests or excites you and brings you joy. once you identify that, tailor it to see how it can apply or add value to others. this way, you intersect fun and impact.

summary.topic: think about what interests you and how it applies to others.
summary.summary: it was interesting because i do end-of-year reflections and think about how my experiences might apply to others. this helped me tailor my content to resonate with both my own reflections and what might interest others. creating content this way is very engaging.

summary.topic: compared creating to baking a cake - different ingredients lead to different results.
summary.summary: like baking a cake, creating content involves mixing different ingredients like theme, script, and visuals. in my "23 lessons from 2023" series, the first five videos had the same introduction and didn't gain traction. changing the intro with a strong hook caused one video to go viral, which boosted the popularity of similar content that followed.

summary.topic: experimentation is important but balance it with a consistent theme.
summary.summary: consistency in your series lets you experiment with style and storytelling while retaining a core theme. before your series blew up, you questioned its future and sought feedback from others. one key takeaway was the importance of actively seeking out your audience if they aren't finding you.

summary.topic: reach out and find other creators in your community.
summary.summary: spent a lot of time on Instagram finding creators who inspired me and helped me learn. found Adrien and his Discord where he reviewed and gave feedback on people's work. his positive reaction to my YouTube video gave me huge motivation even without lots of views or followers. if you don't get the attention you want, go find it.

summary.topic: if feeling unnoticed, go find the right people and try to make them notice you.
summary.summary: show up, make people notice you, and find other creators. my account eventually blew up, but going viral didn't solve everything or change my life dramatically. imposter syndrome still stuck around, so remember that virality won't solve your problems. the key is to keep showing up.

summary.topic: going viral doesn't solve all your problems; it’s more important to enjoy the process.
summary.summary: just focusing on enjoying the process and having fun is key. going viral won't solve your problems, so I recommend balancing content creation with other aspects of life. i signed on to a full-time job in january, which lets me treat content creation as a fun outlet instead of my main income, avoiding the pitfalls of relying solely on sponsorships.

summary.topic: i signed onto a full-time job to keep the fun in content creation.
summary.summary: having a job lets me keep content creation fun and allows me to experiment without stressing over engagement rates. i'm working on improving my relationship with creating content, finding my style, and continually improving as a creative.

summary.topic: having a job lets me experiment without stressing about engagement rates.
summary.summary: i've realized the biggest differentiator is being authentically you. if you show up as yourself, the right people will find you. create more, consume less, and stay true to your unique style.

summary.topic: continually improve your content creation relationship and find your style.
summary.summary: i don't know if anyone has any questions but

summary.topic: show up authentically and create more, consume less.
summary.summary: i've been working on my youtube channel for a couple of years and grew from 300 to 700 subscribers, eventually monetizing it. my biggest fear was that monetizing would make it less fun, and it did, due to the challenge of finding authentic relationships with sponsors while still creating genuine content. i'm still learning and just wanted to hear your thoughts on this.
